description: Frequentative form of dwine, from Middle English dwinen, from Old English dwīnan (“to waste away”), equivalent to dwine +‎ -le, akin to Old Norse dvena, dvína, Dutch verdwijnen (“to disappear, dwindle”).

verbs.description: dwindle (third-person singular simple present dwindles, present participle dwindling, simple past and past participle dwindled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To decrease, shrink, diminish, reduce in size or intensity.
examples: Synonyms: peter out, (figuratively) spin down, trail off

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To fall away in quality; degenerate, sink.
examples: The larger the empire, the more dwindles the mind of the citizen.
